summaries.body: Secretary of State John Kerry made a surprise visit to Baghdad, promising continuing American military and humanitarian aid in the fight against the Islamic State.

display_asset.caption: President Xi Jinping of China at the annual National People’s Congress in Beijing. The Economist and Time have published articles examining the tightening control Mr. Xi has exerted over Chinese politics.

summaries.body: China has blocked the websites for Time and The Economist, apparently over recent cover articles critical of the growing power of China’s president, Xi Jinping.
Trent Harmon was named the 15th and final winner of "American Idol" on Thursday night, but the series finale was above all a celebration of better times for the show.

display_asset.caption: Tourists and a copy of a Viking ship in Stockholm.

summaries.body: Now you can call a random Swede from anywhere in the world, as part of a tourism promotion. A Times reporter made a few calls.

display_asset.caption: Protesters in Hong Kong on Friday demanding the release of activists in mainland China sentenced to prison after being convicted of “incitement to subvert state power.”

summaries.body: In Hong Kong, a young leader of the 2014 pro-democracy protests is starting a new political party. In mainland China, two men are going to prison for raising a banner in support of those protests.
Uber will pay up to $25 million to settle a civil lawsuit with the district attorneys in Los Angeles and San Francisco over claims that it doesn't do enough to scrutinize its drivers.
Two parents who left the Church of Scientology tried to reach out to their children with a billboard message that reads: "To my loved one in Scientology ... Call me."

display_asset.caption: An advertisement for a Chinese news and web portal in Beijing. China blocks some of the biggest corporate names on the Internet, including services offered by Google, Facebook, Twitter and others.

summaries.body: United States trade officials have for the first time added China’s system of Internet filters and blocks to an annual list of trade impediments.

display_asset.caption: The Ramones in a rarely seen image from 1976. From left, Johnny, Tommy, Joey and Dee Dee.

summaries.body: A rare image from the Ramones' early days is now on display at the Queens Museum. In the photograph, the band members are doing something unexpected: smiling.
Some public health advocates in Britain are pushing to have foods labeled to show how much exercise is needed to burn off the calories they contain.

display_asset.caption: Keith Tao of Danville, Calif., finds the fuel-saving start-stop technology irritating. “It can drive you totally insane,” he said.
display_asset.credit: Jason Henry for The New York Times

summaries.body: Start-stop technology may drive some people crazy, but it is here to stay. The system saves fuel by cutting the engine when the car comes to a stop.

display_asset.caption: A wolverine in the Bridger Mountains north of Bozeman, Mont. A federal court ruling revived the debate over whether the animal, a member of the weasel family, is endangered.

summaries.body: Debate over protection for wolverines was revived this week when a Montana judge said the reclusive animal might fall victim to reduced snowfall from climate change.

display_asset.caption: An artist’s rendering of an inflatable module, right, that could expand space station living space.

summaries.body: SpaceX will resume cargo deliveries for NASA on Friday after a nine-month hiatus because of rocket failure, which led to a revamped design and manufacturing process.

display_asset.caption: Gov. Mike Pence of Indiana has been the focus of an unusual campaign on Facebook and Twitter over an abortion law he signed.

summaries.body: Angry women are posting details of their menstrual cycles on social media and directing them at Gov. Mike Pence of Indiana, who signed a new law on abortion restrictions.

display_asset.caption: Ice Cube, one of the core members of N.W.A, which will be inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame.
display_asset.credit: Paras Griffin/Getty Images for Warner Bros

summaries.body: N.W.A. will become the fifth hip-hop act inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame. Ice Cube, one of the group's core members, discussed the honor with The Times.

display_asset.caption: A video image of a San Antonio officer’s confrontation with a middle school student. He has been put on leave.

summaries.body: A middle school police officer in San Antonio was put on leave after a cellphone video showed him throwing a girl face first to the sidewalk.

display_asset.caption: Officials in Iran preparing a noose for an execution in 2014. Amnesty International said in its annual report that almost 90 percent of the executions that it recorded last year were carried out in Iran, Pakistan and Saudi Arabia.

summaries.body: At least 1,634 people were executed last year, the highest total in a quarter-century, Amnesty International said in its annual report on capital punishment.

display_asset.caption: Buffalo Bills linebacker AJ Tarpley, shown intercepting a pass against the New York Jets in January, announced his retirement from the N.F.L. on his Instagram account.

summaries.body: A.J. Tarpley, a 23-year old linebacker with the Buffalo Bills, will retire from the N.F.L. because of repeated concussions, the latest young player to walk away from football.

display_asset.caption: Female Navy recruits in Great Lakes, Ill. They were among the first women to be issued the white hats for enlistees, or Dixie cups, as part of the Navy’s efforts for uniformity in service members’ uniforms.
display_asset.credit: U.S. Navy photo by Sue Krawczyk

summaries.body: The Navy distributed the iconic hats called Dixie cups (also known as “dog dishes” and “squid lids”) to female recruits, part of an effort to make its uniforms gender-neutral.

display_asset.caption: Smokeless tobacco products are now banned at New York City athletic facilities that issue tickets.

summaries.body: Newly signed legislation prohibits the use of smokeless tobacco at New York City sports facilities that issue tickets, including Yankee Stadium and Citi Field.

display_asset.caption: Kesha as she left New York State Supreme Court in Manhattan in February.

summaries.body: A New York State judge rejected claims of emotional and sexual abuse by the pop singer Kesha in her legal fight against the producer Dr. Luke.

display_asset.caption: The writer Calvin Trillin, center, at an after-party in New York at the restaurant China Grill. He has written extensively about cuisine, including Chinese food in the United States.
display_asset.credit: Christian Hansen for The New York Times

summaries.body: Critics say a poem in The New Yorker by the writer Calvin Trillin, about the varieties of Chinese cuisine now available, is dismissive and possibly racist.
Democratic lawmakers in Ohio called for an investigation after a politician said young Republicans would get preference for summer jobs at a state agency.

display_asset.caption: The newly discovered Shakespeare First Folio is bound in three volumes.

summaries.body: Just in time for the global commemoration of the 400th anniversary of Shakespeare’s death, a previously unknown First Folio has been unveiled.

display_asset.caption: Allie Long (23) scoring with a header during the United States’ rout of Colombia in an exhibition game Wednesday.
display_asset.credit: Mark L. Baer/USA Today Sports, via Reuters

summaries.body: As they fight for equal pay, the United States women’s national soccer team whipped outclassed Colombia, 7-0, while drawing another large audience.
An entire village in Britain that has been owned by one family for over 150 years is on sale for about $28 million. The offer includes a mansion, 43 homes and a pub.
The Consumer Products Safety Commission has recalled 20,000 Ivanka Trump scarves because of flammability risks. The scarves are made of rayon in China.
Unmarried couples in Florida can now live together without fear of legal repercussions. The state’s governor signed into law a bill repealing a 148-year-old ban.
France's Parliament has passed a bill to discourage prostitution by penalizing clients who pay for sex. First-time offenders will be fined about $1,700.

display_asset.caption: Gay Talese, whose comments on female writers at a conference in Boston put him in an unfamiliar forum — on Twitter.

summaries.body: Gay Talese set off a Twitter storm after he was asked which female writers inspired him most. The 84-year-old nonfiction writer replied: "None."
